Developing high-performance catalysts for the direct production of isobutanol through the Guerbet reaction is a challenge today, due to the potential of isobutanol as fuel. The present study describes the synthesis and characterization of Cu-supported hydroxyapatite catalysts. The synthesis of isobutanol has been investigated through batch experiments and in a continuous-flow reactor operating in a gas-solid phase. This study used ethanol and methanol as the primary feedstock for the synthesis process. It was found that Cu supported hydroxyapatite catalysts are capable of catalyzing the formation of isobutanol from CH3OH and C2H5OH at temperatures (300–500 ºC) and 1 atm in a continuous flow reactor. Notably, the highest selectivity to isobutanol was observed at 400 ºC. The use of Cu10/HAP 1.65 catalyst in a batch reactor greatly enhances the selectivity of iBuOH in the liquid phase, increasing it from 18 % (vapor-phase) to 65 %. The data showed that the reaction of ethanol/methanol was limited by the 1-propanol-to-isobutanol reaction, which is a secondary reaction of the key intermediate. A reaction scheme has been proposed. Graphical Abstract Keywords Isobutanol Bioethanol Copper-hydroxyapatite Guerbet reaction 1 Introduction Liquid biofuels derived from renewable resources, such as lignocellulosic materials, have been studied for several years. Ethanol (EtOH) is the most widely used liquid biofuel due to its production from renewable sources and its lower toxicity than other alcoholic fuels [1,2]. However, ethanol has drawbacks as a fuel due to its corrosive nature, low energy density, high vapor pressure, and higher water solubility than gasoline [1,3–5]. In internal combustion engines, including those used in oil and diesel engines, higher alcohols such as n-butanol (n-BuOH), isobutanol (iBuOH) and 1-propanol (1-PrOH) offer notable advantages over short-chain alcohols such as EtOH and methanol (MeOH) [6–8]. Isobutanol, in particular, emerges as the preferred biofuel due to its energy density [9], high octane number [10–12], and because it is formed as a kinetic end product through an aldol condensation chain growth process. In addition, n-butanol and isobutanol-gasoline blends have been reported to produce lower concentrations of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons than pure gasoline, and a decrease in nitrogen oxide emissions is observed at high loads with the alcohol blends [13–15]. These higher alcohols can be synthesized by catalytic conversion using the Guerbet reaction, which consists of a general multi-step reaction sequence involving ( Scheme 1): (i) alcohol dehydrogenation, (ii) hydrogen transfer (or borrowed hydrogen chemistry), (iii) dehydration, and (iv) aldol condensation [16–22]. The use of hydroxyapatite (HAP) catalyst with a good balance of moderate strength acid and base sites fosters the upgrading of ethanol to n-butanol [19,23–31] with distinctive selectivity and enhanced catalytic activity. Specifically, the HAP catalyst with a Ca/P molar ratio of 1.67 demonstrated selectivity towards n-butanol production in a fixed bed reactor at 272 ºC, achieving a selectivity of approximately 71 % [23]. While considerable progress has been made in the upgrading of ethanol to n-butanol, as highlighted earlier, investigation of its branched isomer, isobutanol, has scarcely been explored, despite its potential as an advanced liquid biofuel with a higher octane number than n-butanol. Isobutanol can be produced by the Guerbet reaction through converting mixtures of methanol + ethanol or methanol + propanol. This is typically done in a batch reactor at low temperatures ranging from 150 to 200 ºC, under high pressures of 40–80 atm, and strong bases such sodium methoxide or sodium hydroxide are used as catalytic component. Additionally, the homogenous or heterogeneous catalyst are preactivated in situ under harsh conditions (high pressure and hydrogen). In spite of this, some homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been reported for isobutanol production by Guerbet condensation, using different feedstock such as ethanol + methanol or methanol + propanol mixture [18,33–39]. The use of heterogeneous Cu-based catalysts (Cu-Raney and Cu 1955-P) for the condensation of MeOH and 1-PrOH in batch reactor has been reported, exhibiting nearly complete selectivity towards isobutanol [34], although sodium methoxide was used as a catalytic component and activation step for the catalysts with methanol/H2 at 80 atm and 180 ºC is required. However, there is limited information on the catalytic conversion of methanol and ethanol to isobutanol: e.g. through homogeneous catalysis in a batch reactor system using sodium methoxide (ruthenium diphosphine complexes, homogeneous catalysts) [18] or sodium hydroxide (Ir catalyst supported on N-Carbon support, but with high reaction time of 16 h) [40] as a basic agent and in liquid phase in a pressured system at 30 atm of N2 and 180 ºC with chromium and copper catalysts [35] and in a continuous system using oxide catalysts [41] and a mixture of Cu-Mg-Al oxides (propanol and butanol are the main products and the isobutanol production as traces) [38,42]. In particular, CuMgAl catalysts achieved an isobutanol selectivity of 80 % in a continuous flow reactor at 280 ºC and a contact time of 20 g h mol−1, from a starting mixture of methanol and 1-propanol [36]. Co-hydroxyapatite catalyst has been reported for the reaction of methanol + ethanol on continuous reactor at a reaction temperature of 300–375 ºC, where the distribution of aromatic alcohol products can be controlled by adjusting the methanol pressure, however, the isobutanol selectivity were between 5 % and 13 % [32]. Isobutanol synthesis, an important process in the production of biofuels and various chemicals, has primarily been explored using batch reactors with homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. However, studies on isobutanol synthesis in continuous reactors using methanol/propanol or methanol/ethanol feedstocks have been limited. This approach offers benefits as it eliminates the need for a base such as NaOH or sodium methoxide. Therefore, our study aims to investigate the impact of reaction temperature on isobutanol synthesis in a continuous reactor using a reactive mixture of methanol and ethanol, without the use of NaOH or sodium methoxide as a catalytic component. The objective of this contribution is to describe the use of a heterogeneous CuHAP catalyst with an initial ethanol/methanol mixture and using sodium hydroxide instead of sodium methoxide as a catalytic component in a batch reactor, since this has not been reported. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalysts synthesis The hydroxyapatite support was prepared by a co-precipitation method [21,40]. A Ca/P molar ratio of 1.65 was used since in ongoing studies, our group found it to be the optimal molar ratio of Ca/P for converting methanol and ethanol. In a typical synthesis, aqueous solutions of 0.6 M calcium nitrate tetrahydrate (Ca(NO3)2･4 H2O, Sigma Aldrich) and 0.3636 M of dibasic ammonium phosphate ((NH4)2HPO4, Sigma Aldrich) were simultaneously added dropwise into a round-bottom glass flask. Then, the resulting suspension was stirred and adjusted with aqueous ammonia (, Sigma Aldrich) to pH of 10. The solution was kept under magnetic agitation at 80 ºC overnight. Subsequently, the precipitate was washed several times with deionized water, recovered by filtration and dried at 140 ºC overnight. Finally, the hydroxyapatite powder was calcined at 600 ºC for 2 h to obtain the HAP 1.65 support. Before being impregnated with copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2･3 H2O, Sigma Aldrich), the support was heated at 60 ºC to remove any impurities. Then, the required amount of an aqueous solution of (Cu(NO3)2･3 H2O) to obtain10 and 15 wt% Cu by incipient wetness impregnation in HAP 1.65. The copper salt solution was slowly added dropwise to the support. The catalyst was then dried at 140 ºC overnight, calcined in static air at 500 ºC for 2 h, and finally reduced at 400 ºC for 2 h in H2 flow. The catalysts were named Cu10/HAP 1.65 and Cu15/HAP 1.65, and generally Cux/HAP 1.65 (where “x” represents the Cu loading of 10 and 15 wt%). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were evaluated by different techniques. XRD analysis was performed on a Bruker D2 Phaser Cu-source powder diffractometer. Cu K α radiation (λ=1.5418 Å) was used with a power setting of 40 kV and 20 mA. Crystalline structures were obtained within Bragg 2θ angle from 5 to 90° a scan rate of 1º/min with a 0.05º 3/s step size was used. The specific surface area (m2/g) and pore size were determined by the Brunaeur-Emmet-Teller (BET) method and the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method using the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms at −196 ºC on a Micromeritics TriStar II Plus. Temperature-programmed reduction by H2 was performed in an AutoChem III apparatus (Micromeritics). The catalyst was firstly cleaned at 150 ºC under 50 mL/min He flow for 30 min. After cooling to 50 ºC, the carrier gas was switched to 5 % H2/Ar (v/v) at 30 mL/min. When the baseline was stable, the temperature was increased up to 800 ºC with a heating rate of 10 ºC/min, while the amount of H2 consumed was measured with (GC-TCD). Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 and CO2 experiments were performed in an Autochem III (Micromeritics) instrument with powdered catalysts. The sample was placed in a quartz tubular reactor and pretreated at 500 ºC under 30 mL/min He flow for 2 h, then cooled down to 40 ºC and exposed to 10 % NH3/He(v/v) or 10 % CO2/He(v/v) stream with a flow rate of 30 mL/min for 15 min. The physisorbed NH3 and CO2 were removed by He purging (30 mL/min) for 30 min. Subsequently, the sample was heated at a ramp rate of 10ºC/min up to 800 ºC and the desorbed NH3 or CO2 was monitored and recorded using a GC-TCD and GC-MS. X-ray photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) data were collected using a Physical Electronics PHI 5700 spectrometer with non-monochromatic Mg-Kα radiation (300 W, 15 kV, 1253.6 eV) for the analysis of the core level signals of the studied elements and with a multichannel detector. Spectra of powdered samples were recorded with a constant pass energy value of 29.35 eV, using a 720 mm diameter analysis area. All the Cux/HAP 1.65 catalysts were calcined and reduced ( Section 2.1 ) before the analysis (except for the H2−TPR analysis, which only was calcined). 2.3 Catalytic activity for the Guerbet reaction 2.3.1 Catalytic activity for the Guerbet reaction in a batch reactor The condensation of methanol and ethanol was carried out in a stainless-steel batch reactor. Typically, 200 mg (0.106−0.125 mm) of previously activated catalyst ( Section 2.1 ), 100 mL of MeOH, 10 mL of EtOH and 1.37 g of NaOH in a batch reactor system (Iberfluid). Prior to the reaction, the reactor was purged with nitrogen. The reaction was performed at 180 ºC under magnetic stirring (800 rpm) at autogenous pressure or pressurized with N2 (30 atm). The reaction profile was followed by collecting at different times through the sample valve and quickly cooling at 0 ºC. Priorly blank experiments were performed at 180 ºC. Reaction samples were collected every 1 h for 6 hours and were diluted with 1-pentanol and 1–3-dichlorobenzene as internal standard, and stored in sealed vials to be subsequently analyzed by gas chromatography, using a Shimazu GB-14A chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector and a CP-Wax 52 CB capillary column. 2.3.2 Catalytic activity for the Guerbet reaction in a continuous flow reactor The methanol and ethanol (10:1, V/V) condensation was carried out at atmospheric pressure in a tubular metallic flow reactor with an internal diameter of 9.1 mm. For these reaction experiments, 200 mg of pelletized catalyst (0.71−0.85 mm) was placed inside the reactor diluted with silicon carbide (SiC, VWR Chemicals) up to 3 mL. The catalysts were reduced in situ at 400 ºC for 2 h, using an H2 flow of 50 mL/min and a heating rate of 5 ºC/min. After cooling at 300 ºC, the reactions were performed at 300, 350, 400, 450 and 500 ºC, at atmospheric pressure with a liquid feed flow of 0.1 mL/min and a N2 flow of 30 mL/min. The liquid samples were collected every 1 h and analyzed by GC-FID Shimazu model GB-14A equipped with a CP-Wax 52 CB capillary column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Cux/HAP 1.65 catalysts Cux/HAP 1.65 catalysts presented the typical diffraction pattern of hydroxyapatite ( Fig. 1) at 2θ= 31.6º (211), 32.2º (112), 32.9º (300) and 34.1º (202) according to the JCPDS 09–0432 [40–45]. Additionally, the Cu0 crystalline phase was detected at 2θ= 43.5º (111) and 50.9 º (200) [47]. When Cu loadings increased from 10 to 15 wt%, the Cu0 crystallite size increased from 35.2 nm to 53.7 nm. As demonstrated in Figure S1, no crystalline planes attributed to Cu oxides have been identified in CuxHAP1.65 catalysts. Although, it is known that the hydroxyapatite characteristics peaks could be overlaid with the crystal planes of CuO (Cu2+, 2 θ = 35.5º, 38º and 48º, JCPDS 45–0937) and Cu2O (Cu1+, 2 θ = 42.6º, 61º and 73º, JCPDS 05–0667); and XPS and TPR techniques were then utilized to investigate the oxidation states of copper species in the CuxHAP 1.65 catalysts. The TPR profiles ( Fig. 2) show a single peak that increases in intensity and temperature as the copper loading increases (235ºC for Cu15/HAP 1.65 and 228ºC for Cu10/HAP 1.65). This H2 consumption peak between 215 and 235 ºC is attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed Cu2+ species to Cu0 [47,48]. These results agree with the XRD patterns (Fig. 1), which showed the formation of Cu0 on the Cux/HAP 1.65 catalysts after reduction at 400 ºC for 2 h in an H2 atmosphere. In the H2-TPR analysis of CuxHAP 1.65 catalysts, a typical multistep CuO reduction process of occurs Cu 2 + → Cu 1 + → Cu 0 . A shoulder reduction peak can be attributed to the reduction of Cu2+ particles at 168 ºC, while the reduction peaks at 218 ºC - 235 ºC are ascribed to the reduction of Cu1+ particles into metallic copper species, Cu0. Increased copper loading at this range in hydroxyapatite support demonstrated negligible effects on the textural properties of the Cux/HAP 1.65 catalysts. Specifically, pore size distribution (25 nm, as shown in Table S1 and Figure S1) remained unchanged. However, the specific surface area increased slightly to 33 m2/g due to the formation of larger crystallite size with higher copper loading. The NH3-TPD desorption profiles ( Fig. 3) showed an asymmetric peak that can be deconvoluted into two peaks related to weak (≈150 ºC) and moderate (≈280 ºC) acid sites [49]. These acid sites can be attributed to the Lewis acid sites from the PO 4 3 − species [20,50]. In addition, the HAP 1.65 support showed a total amount of acid sites of 139 μmol NH3/gcat with a higher number of weak acid sites. The acidity increases with increasing copper loading, from 135 to 149 μmol NH3/gcat ( Table 1), while the number of moderate acid sites decreases with increasing copper weight loading. The addition of copper to the HAP 1.65 support slightly modifies the amount of acid sites, showing a balance between medium and weak acid sites. Other catalysts have been reported to exhibit similar behavior, with increasing acidity with Cu loading [51]. Generally speaking, Cu10HAP 1.65 catalyst showed a decrease and Cu15HAP 1.65 catalyst demonstrated an increase in acid site density with copper incorporation, from 139 to 135 μmol NH3/gcat and from 139 to 149 μmol NH3/gcat, respectively (see Table 1). Although, particularly the number of weak acid sites increased, while the number of medium acid sites decreases with increasing copper weight loading for Cu10HAP 1.65 and Cu15HAP 1.65 catalyst, respectively. The CO2−TPD profiles of Cux/HAP 1.65 ( Fig. 4) demonstrated the presence of around 150–157 μmol CO2/gcat as the basic site density. This suggests that the amount of basic sites increases with increasing copper loading, as shown in Table 1. The HAP 1.65 support indicated a total amount of basic sites of 11 μmol/gcat. The distribution of basic sites is enhanced by the incorporation of copper, with a higher copper loading (Cu15/HAP 1.65 catalyst) promoting the presence of stronger basic sites and favoring a decrease in weak sites. Meanwhile, for the lower copper loading (Cu10/HAP 1.65), the balance of sites is also modified, with a decrease in medium basic sites and increase in the number of weak sites. The high resolution Cu 2p core level spectra of Cu10/HAP 1.65 and Cu15/HAP 1.65 ( Fig. 5) showed two main peaks at around 952.6 eV and 932.6 eV, corresponding to the doublet Cu 2p 1/2 and Cu 2p 3/2, respectively. To our knowledge, the Cu 2 P3/2 binding energy can not distinguish between Cu1+ and Cu0, as they are nearly identical. Consequently, Auger CuLMM spectra of CuxHAP 1.65 catalysts (see Figure S3, supplementary information) were used to identify the chemical state of copper surface species, Cu0 917.4 or 917.7 eV, and Cu1+ 916.5 or 916.7 eV [47,52,53]. The Cu+/Cu0 ratio decreased from 1.87 to 1.55 with the Cu loading ( Table 2 and Figure S2), modifying the dehydrogenation/hydrogenation properties. Copper-based catalysts are known to promote the Guerbet reaction by assisting in the step of dehydrogenation reactions and the subsequent coupling reactions involving C-O and C-C bonds. Section 3.2 will discuss the effect of these properties on isobutanol production, with a focus on how changes in the Cu+/Cu0 species ratio on the surface improve product selectivity. Furthermore, the Ca/P molar ratio decreased from 1.46 (HAP 1.65 support) to 1.26 and 1.28 as a function of Cu wt% (Table 2). This could be attributed to a substitution of Ca ions for Cu species during the Cu incorporation since it has been reported the partial substitution of Ca ions by e.g. Cu, Co, Zn, etc. It has been established that the hexagonal apatite-type crystal structure of the hydroxyapatite materials remains stable during this chemical modification [46,54]. Figure S3 and Table S2 show the O 1 s, Ca 2p and P 2p of a) Cu10/HAP 1.65 and b) Cu15/HAP 1.65. The O 1 s peak was deconvoluted in three contributions at ≈533 eV attributed to oxygens of adsorbed H2O on the HAP surface, another peak at ≈531 eV assigned to the oxygen from the phosphate groups and OH− groups of hydroxyapatite structure and the carbonates adsorbed on HAP surface, finally, the peak at ≈529 eV was assigned to the oxygen bonds of CaO on the HAP 1.65 structure [55]. The Ca 2p core level spectrum showed the typical doublet Ca 2p 3/2-Ca 2p 1/2 with the maximum of the Ca 2p 3/2 signal at ≈347.3 eV assigned to the HAP's characteristic of Ca2+ species. The peak at ≈133 eV (P 2p 3/2) was attributed to the P−O bonds of the HAP [55]. As shown in this study, CuxHAP 1.65 catalysts were found to contains Cu1+ and Cu0 copper species based on the results of XRD and H2-TPR techniques. It is important to note that XRD and H2-TPR are bulk analyses, meaning they analize the entire composition rather than specifically the surface like the XPS technique does. As a result we identified metallic copper (Cu0) species on the catalyst surface using XRD and TPR analyses, along with the Cu1+ species identified by XPS analysis. It is reasonable to assume that the strong interaction between copper nanoparticles and the hydroxyapatite support induced the coexistence of copper species as Cu1+ and Cu0 on the catalyst surface of fresh catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic Guerbet condensation of MeOH with EtOH to give isobutanol: batch and continuous flow reactor 3.2.1 Effect of reaction time in batch reactor The methanol and ethanol coupling reaction was performed in liquid phase at 180 ºC and 30 atm of N2 atmosphere and the results are shown in Fig. 6. The conversion of EtOH increases in a steady state as the reaction time is increased for all catalysts. It is observed that the addition of Cu to the hydroxyapatite support enhances the catalytic activity. A significant improvement in ethanol conversion was observed, increasing from 44 % to 49 % with hydroxyapatite support. Despite an increased in copper loading from 10 wt% to 15 wt% in the CuxHAP 1.65 catalyst, the ethanol conversion remained nearly identical, ranging from 45 % to 58 %. It is noteworthy that the addition of Cu to the hydroxyapatite support enhances the catalytic activity. Furthermore, both reaction time and copper loading demonstrated a beneficial impact on ethanol conversion. The loading of copper evidently influences the distribution of the product to a greater extent. Specifically, the selectivity to iBuOH increases significantly with Cu loading and reaction time: HAP 1.65 (5–31 %), Cu15/HAP 1.65 (32–53 %), and Cu10/HAP 1.65 (27–64.8 %). The copper loading on the CuxHAP1.65 catalyst substantially affects its performance, as shown in previous studies on the methanol + 1-propanol reaction, which is the second step in producing isobutanol using the Guerbet reaction pathway. The Cu10HAP1.65 catalyst requires much less copper compared to Cu-based catalysts with 18 wt% copper loading [36]. Although, the copper reducibility is similar in the Cu10HAP1.65 (35.2 nm) and Cu15HAP1.65 (53.7 nm) catalysts, there are noticeable differences in the basicity and copper crystal size in the fresh catalyst. As a result of the copper loading, modifications in the Cu1+/Cu0 ratio (1.87 and 1.55, Cu10HAP1.65 and Cu15HAP1.65, respectively) impact the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation processes, influencing the acetaldehyde and propanal production and the subsequent conversion to isobutanol through the aldol condensation step. Interestingly, the incorporation of copper into the hydroxyapatite support (Figs. 6 b) and 6 c)) enhanced the selectivity for isobutanol to 65 % as a function of reaction time in compared to the unsupported counterparts ( Fig. 6 a). The results in Fig. 6 also indicate that the selectivity to n-butanol with reaction time increases for Cux/HAP 1.65, whereas it decreases for the HAP sample. Indeed, for HAP, an increase in reaction time unexpectedly raised isobutanol selectivity at the expense of n-butanol selectivity, suggesting that a shorter reaction time (2 h) favored the production of n-butanol, while a longer reaction time (>3 h) led to highly selective isobutanol production. During the reaction with Cux/HAP 1.65 catalysts, isobutanol shows a linear increase in selectivity for 5 h, followed by a decrease over the next hour of reaction time. The selectivity of propanaldehyde decreases during the first 5 h and then experiences an increase. Within the 6 h reaction time interval, the selectivity towards 1-propanol and acetaldehyde indicates a linear decrease. On the other hand, the selectivity toward n-butanol increases gradually, reaching a plateau between 3 and 6 h of reaction time. An interesting behavior is observed between the selectivities of propanaldehyde and isobutanol. The production of the latter is closely related to the formation and conversion of propanal, which is produced by the dehydrogenation of 1-propanol (step III to step IV, see reaction scheme Fig. 7). During the synthesis of isobutanol, the reaction time and the liquid reaction phase are crucial under our adopted reaction conditions. The results (Fig. 6) show that the iBuOH selectivity gradually increases with time from 27.4 (1 h) to 64.8 % (5 h), demonstrating that the reaction time is important to improve the isobutanol production. A correlation has been found between the relationship of basic and acidic properties and the number of surface Cu+/Cu0 species for the selectivity and conversion towards isobutanol using Cux/HAP1.65 catalysts. This has enhanced tailored control over-reactivity and selectivity in the Guerbet reaction. In particular, decreasing Cu loading increased the distribution of smaller Cu crystallites and elucidated the structure-activity relationship of Cux/HAP1.65 support interactions for isobutanol synthesis. Furthermore, the selectivity toward isobutanol is higher with the Cu10/HAP1.65 catalyst, which shows the highest basicity/acidity ratio (1.12) and the highest value of surface Cu+/Cu0 species of 1.87. On the contrary, when using the Cu15/HAP 1.65 catalyst, the isobutanol selectivity is lower which can be attributed to a lower basicity/acidity ratio (1.05) and Cu+/Cu0 ratio (1.55), which affected the product distribution. The reason for this is that increasing the amount of copper in the catalyst leads to the formation of larger crystals and strong basic sites, while reducing the amount of weak basic sites. As a result, it was observed that the ratio of basicity to acidity decreases to 1.05 and there are 1.55 Cu+/Cu0 surface copper species. Basic sites of medium and weak strength show a strong correlation with selectivity to isobutanol. However, Cu+/Cu0 species had a positive effect on catalyzing aldol reactions, dehydrogenation and hydrogenation, while Cu+ and Cu0 demonstrated a synergistic effect on isobutanol production. Studies have reported that the Cu+ species serves as both the active site for dehydrogenation and hydrogenation, while the Cu0 site enables the transfer of hydrogen atoms on the catalyst surface [56–58]. Furthermore, the yield towards isobutanol achieved in a gas-phase reaction was 4.8 % with Cu10/HAP 1.65 (SI, Table S3), which increased to a maximum value of 36.6 % in a liquid-phase reaction with the same catalyst. Moreover, during the pressurized reaction with N2, in liquid phase, additional reaction byproducts were recognized: acetaldehyde (Ace) resulting from the dehydrogenation of ethanol (Step I and II of Route 1 in Fig. 7), and propionaldehyde (PrCHO) formed through the dehydrogenation of 1-PrOH (Step III and IV of Route 1 in Fig. 7). The identification of these aldehydes as intermediate products aligns with literature findings [16,30], contributing to a better understanding of the condensation reaction mechanism involving ethanol and methanol (see Fig. 7, reaction scheme proposed). The catalytic activity was improved when it was carried out in the liquid phase by pressurizing the reactor with 3 MPa of N2, avoiding the vaporization of intermediates and reaction products and improving the interaction between methanol and ethanol or intermediate products and catalyst [18]. The Guerbet reaction, which produces isobutanol from mixtures of ethanol/methanol and propanol/methanol, with an organometallic catalyst and CuMgAl (18.5 wt% Cu) [34] has been described to be highly selective to isobutanol when sodium methoxide is used as a catalytic component. Notably, we replaced the sodium methoxide base with sodium hydroxide, a less corrosive base, and, in addition, we used an ethanol/methanol mixture, which is less reactive than the propanol/methanol mixture, achieving similar selectivities for isobutanol [18,33]. On the other hand, the addition of Cu to the catalyst seems to inhibit the parallel ethanol self-condensation to n-BuOH (Route 2 in Fig. 7), since the selectivity to this alcohol decreased from 47 % (HAP 1.65) to values below 10 % with Cu-supported catalysts [18,33]. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction temperature on isobutanol selectivity in a continuous flow reactor Fig. 8 shows the catalytic results during the condensation reaction of MeOH and EtOH in the fixed bed reactor. As expected, as the reaction temperature increases from 300 to 500 ºC, ethanol conversion increases for both catalysts whereas isobutanol selectivity (pink lines) reaches a maximum at 400ºC. A comparable gradual trend was observed in the ethanol conversion with varying copper loadings in the CuxHAP1.65 catalysts (Cu10HAP1.65 −35.2 nm crystal size- and Cu15HAP1.65 −53.7 nm crystal size), rising from 42 % to 60 % with changes in both copper loading and reaction temperature. Increasing the amount of copper in the catalyst can affect the strength of the basic sites and the ratio of Cu1+ to Cu0 surface species, which in turn changes the overall performance and selectivity of the catalyst in the reaction. The effect is particularly striking when examining the selectivity trends of CuxHAP1.65 catalysts, especially in the case of 1-propanol and isobutanol. At a lower reaction temperature of 300 ºC, increasing the copper loading from 10 wt% (Cu10HAP1.65) to 15 wt% (Cu15HAP1.65) resulted in a significant rise in the 1-propanol selectivity from 34 % to 51 %, while conversely, the isobutanol selectivity decreased from 34 % to 16 %. Meanwhile, the 1-propanol and PrCHO (propionaldehyde) selectivities decrease, suggesting that 1-PrOH and PrCHO are intermediate products involved in the isobutanol production (see step III to step IV of the reaction scheme, Fig. 7). This suggests that although the dehydrogenation reaction occurs, the aldol condensation of PrCHO with formaldehyde to produce iBuOH is limited (step IV to step V, scheme reaction), resulting in a decrease in the iBuOH selectivity. Conversely, when the Cu15/HAP 1.65 catalyst was utilized, the 1-PrOH selectivity decreased slightly from 32 % to 30 %, even though remaining higher than when the catalyst with a lower copper loading was used. Moreover, the conversion of 1-propanol-to-isobutanol (step III to step V, reaction scheme, Fig. 7) emerges as the rate-determining step in the overall reaction sequence for isobutanol synthesis. Interestingly, the reaction between ethanol and methanol yielded an n-butanol selectivity of around 18 % for the Cu15/HAP 1.65 catalyst in the vapor-phase of the batch reactor (table S3, SI), while in the liquid phase of the batch reactor, the selectivity of n-BuOH was around 10 %. However, for both catalysts, the selectivity of n-butanol decreased below 5 % in the continuous reactor. This demonstrates an advantage of carrying out the reaction of methanol with ethanol in a continuous flow reactor, allowing the selectivity of isobutanol to be increased while maintaining the selectivity of n-butanol at a minimum value. At 400 ºC, the Cu10/HAP 1.65 and Cu15/HAP 1.65 catalysts exhibited the highest selectivities toward isobutanol (62.2 and 46.1 %, respectively). W. Ueda et al. [41], reported that at 390 ºC, the selectivity for iBuOH over MgO catalysts was higher (46 %) than at lower temperatures. Furthermore, the 1-propanol and PrCHO selectivities decrease with temperature, suggesting that 1-PrOH and PrCHO are being converted into isobutanol, as expected. Nonetheless, as Fig. 8 shows, Cu15/HAP 1.65 displayed significantly higher selectivity to 1-PrOH than Cu10/HAP 1.65. This is attributed to the lower Cu+/Cu0 and base/acid ratio exhibited by the catalyst with 15 wt% of Cu. This suggests that the conversion of 1-PrOH to PrCHO and iBuOH is less efficient with this catalyst compared to Cu10/HAP 1.65. Interestingly, the selectivity towards n-BuOH decreased (below 5 %) in the continuous reactor, in comparison with the vapor-phase batch reactor (≈16 %, table S3, SI) and the liquid-phase batch reactor (≈10 %). Using a continuous flow reactor for methanol with ethanol reaction improves isobutanol selectivity and reduces n-butanol selectivity by suppressing ethanol self-condensation in Route 2 (Fig. 7 ). It is worth mentioning that high selectivity and yield (77.5 %) to isobutanol have been reported [34] but using a CH3OH/C3H7OH mixture as feedstock, which contributes to the rate-determining step with our catalysts, and a high contact time of 20 g h/mol, whereas we used 1.4 g h/mol. Although our highest isobutanol yield is 33.9 % (Figure S4), both our contact time and copper loading are lower compared to those reported. Particularly, our contact time is shorter and the copper loading used by us is less than 18.5 wt%. Currently, our research group is conducting further studies to investigate the effect of contact time on isobutanol yield. As previously indicated, the Guerbet reaction of MeOH and EtOH requires the presence of metal sites (Cu0) and basic/acidic sites to undergo dehydrogenation, aldol condensation, and hydrogenation reactions, which are necessary for the synthesis of Guerbet products (C3; 1-PrOH, PrCHO and C4; iBuOH and n-BuOH). The results show a close relationship between the Cu+/Cu0 ratio and the selectivity towards iBuOH. Similar to basic/acidic species; it decreased with increasing Cu loading in the HAP 1.65 support. On the other hand, in agreement with Cheng et al. [38], we found high selectivity for C3 and C4 products such as 1-PrOH, PrCHO, iBuOH and n-BuOH (Figure S5). Both catalysts showed higher production of C3 products (1-PrOH and PrCHO) at low reaction temperatures. This is attributed to the fact that 1-PrOH is formed at low temperatures by increasing the reaction temperature, this intermediate is more likely to be transformed to iBuOH. The formation of C4 products was higher at 400 ºC, due to a higher yield value of isobutanol at this reaction temperature. The Cu10/HAP1.65 catalyst demonstrates a gradual enhancement in isobutanol yield, reaching the best value of 33.9 % at the reaction temperature of 400 ºC. In contrast, Cu15/HAP1.65 shows an increase in the yield of isobutanol from 300 to 450 ºC, but decreases at 500 ºC. To elucidate the relationship between isobutanol selectivity (product distribution), basicity and Cu+/Cu0 species, we have plotted the changes in isobutanol selectivity against the ratio of weak/medium basic sites and Cu+/Cu0 ratio (see Figure S5). The selectivity for isobutanol demonstrates a positive correlation with the ratio of weak/medium basic sites and the Cu+/Cu0 ratio. This indicates the potential for a synergistic effect between Cu1+ and Cu0 species in influencing isobutanol selectivity. As mentioned previously, the incorporation of copper to the catalyst surface increases the Cu1+/Cu0 ratio and creates weak/medium basic sites when the catalyst has a lower copper loading (10 wt%), Cu1oHAP1.65. Furthermore, the Guerbet reaction of methanol + ethanol needs dehydrogenation, aldol condensation, and hydrogenation reactions (see Scheme 1 and Fig. 7), all of which require the participation of metal sites (in our case Cu1+/Cu0 species) and basic/acid sites. Specifically, it was observed that the production of isobutanol can be facilated by the Cu10HAP1.65 catalyst which showed the highest ratio for both Cu1+/Cu0 species and weak/medium basic sites. Based on the results (see Figure S5), it is noteworthy that the low copper loading optimizes the balance between weak/medium basic sites for aldol condensation reactions (propanal + formaldehyde to produce isobutanol) and Cu1+/Cu0 species for dehydrogenation and hydrogenation reactions. 3.2.3 Catalytic condensation of methanol and ethanol in a fixed bed reactor: time on stream study and recycling test Considering that the Cu10/HAP 1.65 catalyst showed higher selectivity and yield towards isobutanol at 400 ºC, its stability was studied at this temperature was studied for 6 h. Fig. 9 shows that the EtOH conversion decreased slightly over time, from 56.9 % to 52.7 %. The catalyst showed excellent stability to produce isobutanol since the selectivity towards this product only decreased from 62 % to 56 % in 6 h. On the other hand, the 1-PrOH selectivity decreased with time, while propionaldehyde increased. Furthermore, the recycling results showed good carbon balance values in the catalyst stability reaction 82.7−85.2 %. These results indicated that the Cu10/HAP 1.65 catalyst is stable for at least 6 h of reaction at 400 °C. Fig. 9 shows that the EtOH conversion decreased slightly over time, from 58 % to 51 % (fresh and spent catalyst). The deactivation of the Cu10HAP 1.65 catalyst is likely caused by the deposition of carbonaceous materials on the surface and through the agglomeration/growth of copper nanoparticles. The results showed a slight decrease in EtOH conversion and selectivity to iBuOH. We observed that both ethanol conversion and isobutanol selectivity slowly decline with time on stream, tending to a 55 % (fresh catalyst, and 50 % spent catalyst) and 58 % (fresh catalyst, and 50 % spent catalyst), while the propanal selectivity increases progressively from 15 % (fresh catalyst, and 17 % spent catalyst) to 27 % (fresh catalyst, and 28 % spent catalyst). The yields to iBuOH decreased from 34.9 % (the first hour of reaction of the fresh catalyst) to 24.1 % (the sixth hour of reaction of the spent catalyst). Indeed, the Cu+/Cu0 ratio for fresh and spent catalyst decreased from 1.87 to 1.66, respectively (Figures S6 and S7). Moreover, the surface carbon composition increased from 15.1 to 15.9 wt% which confirm that a possible deposition of organic material occurs on the catalyst surface. However, the surface amount of Cu increased from 5.4 to 8.7 wt%. This could be attributed to the increase of Cu particles after the reaction. This was confirmed by XRD analysis (Figure S8), where the size of the Cu0 crystallite was found to increase from 35.2 nm (fresh) to 38.8 nm (spent catalyst) which could be attributed to the growth or agglomeration of copper particles. This suggested that the Cu0 species were more prominently present on the surface of the spent catalyst. Consequently, the decrease in the Cu+/Cu0 ratio can be attributed to this exposure of Cu0 species on the surface. Regardless, the SSA remained at a value of 31 m2/g (fresh 28 m2/g), but the average pore size reduced from 25.5 to 13.4 nm in fresh and spent catalysts, respectively (Figure S9). This is attributed to mesopore obstruction resulting from increased Cu size and coke deposition. This experiment suggests that aldol condensation to produce isobutanol active sites is progressively deactivated (as Cu+1/Cu0 ratio decreases) by carbon deposition or by copper sintering (as crystallite size shown to increase), and this results in an increasing propanal selectivity. 4 Conclusions The results have shown that a significant improvements in catalytic performance are obtained when CuxHAP 165 catalysts are evaluated in a vapor-pase batch reactor, liquid-phase batch reactor and vapor phase in a fixed bed reactor (as a function of reaction temperature from 300 ºC to 500 ºC). Particularly when Cu10/HAP 1.65 catalyst was used in a batch reactor, the selectivity for iBuOH increased from 18 % in the vapor-phase to 65 % in the liquid phase. A positive effect is observed with the reaction time in the liquid-phase batch reactor, as it aids in identifying key intermediate products, such as ACe and PrCHO, while increasing the selectivity for isobutanol and decreasing the selectivity for n-butanol obtained with Cu15/HAP 1.65 catalyst. More importantly, upgrading from a batch reactor to a continuous flow reactor, the Cu10/HAP 1.65 catalyst demonstrated outstanding catalytic performance, 54.5 % ethanol conversion, 62.2 % isobutanol selectivity and 33.9 % isobutanol yield at 400 ºC. Consequently, the selectivity towards n-BuOH was almost inhibited and the use of NaOH base in the catalylitic system was avoided, promising features for industrial applications. Interestingly, Cu modifies the balance of base/acid sites, and greater dispersion is achieved on the Cu10/HAP 165 catalyst. This catalyst can promote a multi-step reaction smoothly, but depending on whether the MeOH with EtOH reaction is conducted in a batch reactor or a continuous flow reactor, the rate-determining step of 1-PrOH/PrCHO to isobutanol becomes more critical. Notably, at lower copper loadings, the basicity/acidity ratio (as determined by TPD) and the Cu+/Cu0 ratio (as determined by XPS) increased. This effect influenced the isobutanol selectivity, resulting in higher values of 64.8 % in a batch system at 30 atm pressure and 62.2 % in a continuous system at 400 ºC with Cu10/HAP 1.65. Cu10/HAP 1.65 catalyst is stable in a packed bed reactor but deactivates due to copper crystallites enlargement during the reaction, reducing surface copper species. coredata.dc:description: Developing high-performance catalysts for the direct production of isobutanol through the Guerbet reaction is a challenge today, due to the potential of isobutanol as fuel. The present study describes the synthesis and characterization of Cu-supported hydroxyapatite catalysts. The synthesis of isobutanol has been investigated through batch experiments and in a continuous-flow reactor operating in a gas-solid phase. This study used ethanol and methanol as the primary feedstock for the synthesis process. It was found that Cu supported hydroxyapatite catalysts are capable of catalyzing the formation of isobutanol from CH3OH and C2H5OH at temperatures (300–500 ºC) and 1 atm in a continuous flow reactor. Notably, the highest selectivity to isobutanol was observed at 400 ºC. The use of Cu10/HAP 1.65 catalyst in a batch reactor greatly enhances the selectivity of iBuOH in the liquid phase, increasing it from 18 % (vapor-phase) to 65 %. The data showed that the reaction of ethanol/methanol was limited by the 1-propanol-to-isobutanol reaction, which is a secondary reaction of the key intermediate. A reaction scheme has been proposed.
